author: @craigwarren4123
text: Hi Harrison, Series is great. Think some may find the explanation of name == main ... a tad confusing. Now, this is just a suggestion for a tutorial rewrite .....  Use the (if __name__ == '__main__': # do something),if you want to run code in your module, that will exclusively run, only when you are directly running your module as someFileNamedotpy versus running your module by way of importing it into another file as in.. import someFileName...              Keep up the great work, it is very much appreciated.

author: @fupopanda
text: This tutorial is your worst in this series so far; probably the only bad one. You essentially skipped the explanation of what ___name___ means.  *For those very new to Python,* ___name___ is a special variable that Python declares before running a module. A module is just another name for a Python file. When a module is run, the variable ___name___ is set to the string ___main__._ If a module is being imported into the main module that is running, the variable ___name___ of the imported module is set to its own name.
